val:
This is gonna be a short series where I share what I went through throughout my professional career to become the professional developer I am today. From unemployed to a self taught developer working at two unicorn companies and now working in a senior role at a startup.

I hope you can get a feel of what might be in store for you if youâ€™re in the initial phase of your own career path or that you can at least realize that, in spite of the ups and downs, things can turn out alright as long as you donâ€™t give up on your passion ğŸ’ª

Code is everywhere

I played video games ever since i was a kid and yet it was only when I was around high school that I realised there are people writing code running in the background of my games and all the software we use daily.

Because of my interest in computers, a friend of mine suggested Iâ€™d try a programming course in high school. I loved video games but I couldnâ€™t imagine myself in a 9 to 5 job â€œworking in ITâ€. I guess in my head this meant sitting at a desk, looking at the insides of a computer and try to fix whatever the reason was for it to be booting up into a blue screen, which sounded dreadful to me at the timeâ€¦ Even though I was skeptical regarding my long term interest in following a career path around computers I took the chance.

â€œHumanityâ€™s problems stem from manâ€™s inability to sit quietly in a room aloneâ€

During the course I had my first ever interaction with code with a programming language called Pascal.

It wasnâ€™t much, I know. Heck, it was just an unimpressive terminal with a white cursor blinking on the screen. But Iâ€™d seen too many hacker movies at that point to know that exciting stuff can happen on a computer console.

The first time I coded basic math for it to return the result of a sum of 2 values I felt like I was hacking into the mainframe. And once I made an â€œappâ€ that prompted the user for their name and returned â€œHello <userâ€™s name>!â€ I knew I was one with the Matrix ğŸ˜

As I continued learning the basics of programming (arrays, functions, etc), and things began to make sense, I started adding more logic and more complexity to my code. Keep in mind that at this point the complexity Iâ€™m describing would be something like asking the user for multiple inputs, processing them and finally present them back. But this was already pretty cool for a noob such as myself!

The feeling of getting the user to trigger an action which had a reaction that Iâ€™d anticipated and prepared for was thrilling! It felt like a puzzle video game where I was given bits and pieces but had to place them together in order to progress and get my reward.

I remember going home and picking up where the last class had left off just because I wanted to see where the rabbit whole ended. Best part was it didnâ€™t! Turns out programming is not so much as a puzzle game as it is a sandbox: it only ends when you want it to.

Homework

A few months past and I already had a pretty good grasp on the basics. At that point Mr. Pascal was no longer enough. I needed someone new, someone fresh and I was ready to go out there and have a taste of what the world has to offer.

I asked my friend who got me in this mess what I should be learning in order to make something actually usable and productive. He was like â€œHave you met HTML? Maybe you should look into that. And CSS. Oh and JavaScript while youâ€™re at it. Could also try PHP if you want.â€

Now, if youâ€™re a beginner Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ve heard these exact words as well (maybe not the PHP part, PHP was more popular back in my day ğŸ‘´). And though it might sound like a lot, it all connects together fairly well.

Web Anatomy

Whenever I have to explain what HTML, CSS and JS are to â€œnon tech peopleâ€ and why theyâ€™re so intertwined - even though they are different languages - I provide a human body analogy to help visualise their purpose:

ğŸ’€ HTML: This is our pageâ€™s skeleton. Itâ€™s the backbone of the web. If everything else falls apart, we can still see the bones of a page and have some sense of what it is trying to accomplish.

ğŸ’… CSS: Ahh the pretty side of any web page. This would be the skin covering our cold, ugly bones. Any skeleton looks a lot friendlier with some skin and some make-up if we want to get fancy.

ğŸ§  JavaScript: JS is the brains of the whole operation. Sure the page is there, standing on its two feet, smooth, pretty and ready to charm anyone that comes by. But how can we greet our visitors without a brain? If we want to understand our tenants we probably should try and get to know them a bit, maybe ask them to fill a newsletter, or even login. Thatâ€™s where the big brain logic comes in.

My first ever web page where I showed off a bunch of HTML tags. I was pretty damn excited about it ğŸš€

The First â€œBig Stepâ€

At the end of my programming course, I had to consolidate everything Iâ€™d learn into a final project.

Being the original waterfall of creativity I naturally am, I decided to made a note taking app ğŸ˜

It wasnâ€™t just about taking notes though, no no no! It had a strong focus on scheduling tasks and notifications for your notes. At the time notifications didnâ€™t get the hate they do todayâ€¦

I thought adding myself to the homepage would make me look pretty cool

TaskPal in its glory days

Since I didnâ€™t know how to develop on mobile devices I couldnâ€™t do push notifications on phones. I could send a browser notification but then Iâ€™d run the chance of TaskPal telling someone they should have left for the airport 6 hours ago because they hadnâ€™t stopped to sit in front of a computer, opened their browser and checked the TaskPal app.

This limitation made me look for alternative solutions. Eventually I found a few APIs that would allow me to send an email or an SMS automatically with a custom message. It was far from a great user experience but got the job done.

TaskPal email notification

This took months of research and development. I had to learn HTML for the page structure; CSS for its styling; SQL (database language) to manage users; PHP to handle the logic of communicating with the front-end, the database and the notification APIs; Photoshop for some graphics and icons; how to integrate the notification APIs and JSON to read data from them.

This was a lot at the time but In the end I was able to complete the project and got 19 points out of 20. I didnâ€™t end up putting the project on the web. I dropped the project a little after that and that was it for TaskPal ğŸª¦

The world was my oyster

Now that I knew what I wanted to do professionally, I was ready for a new chapter.

Where Iâ€™m from, most people assume college is the step right after high school. I was never a big fan of this idea of college being a â€œmust haveâ€ in order to have a decent job. Specially in my case where I knew exactly what I wanted to do and had all the tools required to learn it: a computer and internet connection.

A few people around me insisted Iâ€™d go to college anyway so I gave it a shot. I didnâ€™t want to go for computer science because I knew there was a lot of filler that I wasnâ€™t gonna put into use as a web developer (like network systems, advanced calculus, etc) so I opted for a more â€œmultimediaâ€ focused course which also included web development.

I got in and after a few months of amazing my colleges with my big brain who already knew a few basic html tags I realised that course wasnâ€™t gonna teach me anything I didnâ€™t already know. So I dropped out after one semester ğŸ˜…

I went back to my motherâ€™s house - fortunately she was able to support me for a few months - and I decided to study at home and eventually apply for a job.

I wasnâ€™t really sure where to start. Iâ€™d never had to look for job. I didnâ€™t even know what people excepted from me as a developer. So I looked up vague terms like â€œfront end developer jobâ€ and filtered it for results in my country. By looking up what the market was looking for I was able to learn which technologies were valuable, which skills I still had to develop, what companies were out there, how much they were offering, etc.

I soon realised that I should probably focus my studies more on JavaScript - since it was so requested and it was also something I had a basic understanding of and enjoyed - and into this framework called AngularJS.

Now that I had new goals everything was new again. There was so much I didnâ€™t know, so much I didnâ€™t understand and almost no one to resort to for answers. I was no longer in school, Iâ€™d dropped out and now I had to make this work in order to get the job I wanted. The stakes were higher than ever.

Self promotion

I was never a very good student when it comes to just sit and read what I had to learn. Iâ€™ve always felt the need to put things into practice. Thatâ€™s how I learn, how I understand how things work, their purpose, their advantages and limitations. So whenever I had something new and big to learn (either a new language or new framework) I built side projects.

When I learned HTML I made web forms; when I learned php and sql I made TaskPal; when I learned Vue I made a small setup wizard app to help people speed up the process of installing their productivity apps - whenever they get a new computer - as quickly as possible.

These werenâ€™t brilliant ideas but they all helped me put a purpose into what Iâ€™ve learned and some of them ended up being useful for my personal use.

Now, why am I telling you this? Because looking at so many job ads made me realise something: I had nothing to show off at a job interview. I didnâ€™t have a college degree nor any sort of â€œclients testimoniesâ€ to help me land my first job ever! I knew how to program so could I prove this to a potential employer? I figured I had to build a portfolio. If I couldnâ€™t show grades or a certificate that vouched for me, I had to show actual work that could.

I wasnâ€™t bold enough nor I had a strong entrepreneur vein to start charging people for my unskilled services but I started asking around for ideas. (Un)Surprisingly asking â€œWhat kind of web app would make your life easier?â€ is not something most people can easily answer quickly on the spot.

So I started with myself: Iâ€™m a front end developer. I should at least practice what I preach. So I designed an online page about me so I could at least have a professional presence online.

After that I asked a developer friend of mine whether he had any pending projects or people who he knew that were looking for a website and I would do it pro bono. Most of them werenâ€™t pretty, some didnâ€™t go beyond the mock-up design phase and other projects didnâ€™t even see the light of day. But in the end I had something to show for.

Cliff hanger

With a personal page up online and some projects under my belt, I was ready! I wasnâ€™t confident (confidence was never really my strong suit to be honest) but I knew I had something concrete to present at a possible interview.

Throughout the years I applied to dozens of job ads, dozens of interviews and a lot of rejections. I never really got used to job interviews as I always get nervous, stutter and sometimes even sabotage myself but I learned a lot with them: how to prepare a resume, how to prepare for an interview, how to talk to someone who knows a lot more than you, how to handle a rejection and how to negotiate an offer.

But more on that later ğŸ˜‰

Thanks for reading!

More to come soonâ„¢
